items.markText: I trust that none will stretch the seams in putting on the coat, for it may do good service to him whom it fits.
What is called resignation is confirmed desperation.

To be a philosopher is not merely to have subtle thoughts, nor even to found a school, but so to love wisdom as to live according to its dictates, a life of simplicity, independence, magnanimity, and trust.
The life which men praise and regard as successful is but one kind.Why should we exaggerate any one kind at the expense of the others?
Most of the luxuries, and many of the so-called comforts of life, are not only not indispensable, but positive hindrances[æ’å›¾] to the elevation of mankind.

By the words,necessary of lifeï¼ŒI mean whatever,of all that man obtains by his own exertions, has been from the first, or from long use has become, so important to human life that few, if any, whether from savageness,or poverty, or philosophy, ever attempt to do without it.
but know not how to use it, or get rid of it, and thus have forged their own golden or silver fetters[æ’å›¾].
All men want, not something todo withï¼Œbut somethingto doï¼Œor rathersomething tobe.
a man is rich in proportion to the number of things which he can afford to let aloneï¿¼.

I went to the woods because I wished to live deliberately, to front only theessential facts of life, and see if I could not learn what it had to teach, andnot, when I came to die, discover that I had not lived.
The luxury of one class is counterbalanced[æ’å›¾]by the indigence of another.

The millions are awake enough for physical labor;but only one in a million is awake enough for effective intellectual exertion,only one in a hundred millions to a poetic or divine life.To be awake is to be alive.

When he has obtained those things which are necessary to life, there is another alternative[æ’å›¾] than to obtain the superfluities[æ’å›¾]; and that is, to adventure on life now, his vacation from humbler toil[æ’å›¾] having commenced.

night.Little is to be expected of that day, if it can be called a day, to which we are not awakened by our Genius, but by the mechanical nudging of some servitor, are not awakened by our own newly acquired force and aspirations from within, and a fragrance filling the airâ€”to a higher life than we fell asleep from[æ’å›¾];
The civilized man is a more experienced and wiser savage
to be hindered fromï¿¼ accomplishing which for want of a little common sense, a little enterprise and business talent, appeared not so sad as foolish.
In the long run men hit only what they aim at.Therefore, though they should fail immediately, they had better aim at something high.
To anticipate, not the sunrise and the dawn merely, but, if possible, Nature herself!
Man wanted a home, a place of warmth, or comfort, first of warmth, then the warmth of the affections.
There are none happy in the world but beings who enj oy freely a vast horizonâ€
saw how I could let the years run off, buffetï¿¼ the winter through, and see the spring come in.
To read well, that is, to read true books in a true spirit, is a noble exercise, and one that will task the reader more than any exercise which the customs of the day esteem.
yet I am sure that there is greater anxiety, commonly, to have fashionable, or at least clean and unpatched clothes, than to have a sound conscience.
it frequently happens that after the lapse of a season the latter becomes the most fashionable
Time is but the stream I go a-fishing in.I drink at it; but while I drink I see the sandy bottom and detect how shallow it is.Its thin current slides away, but eternity remains.
What sort of space is that which separates a man from his fellows and makes him solitary? I have found that no exertion of the legs can bringtwo minds much nearer to one another.
While civilization has been improving our houses, it has not equally improved the men who are to inhabit them.It has created palaces, but it was not so easy to create noblemen and kings.
The luxuriously rich are not simply kept comfortably warm, but unnaturally hot; as I implied before, they are cooked, of courseÃ  la modeï¿¼.
men have become the tools of their tools.
I mean that they should not play life, or study it merely, while the community supports them at this expensive game, but earnestly live it from beginning to end.
Every generation laughs at the old fashions, but follows religiously the new.

Being seated, to run through the region of the spiritual world; I have had this advantage in books. To be intoxicated by a single glass of wine; I have experienced this pleasure when I have drunk the liquor of the esoteric[æ’å›¾] doctrines.â€

From the cave we have advanced to roofs of palm leaves, of bark and boughs, of linen woven and stretched, of grass and straw, of boards and shingles, of stones and tiles.
but t-o brag as lustily as chanticleer in the morning, standing on his roost[æ’å›¾]ï¼Œif only to wake my neighbors up.
To affect the quality of the day, that is the highest of arts.
Even thepoorstudent studies and is taught onlypoliticaleconomy, while that economy of living which is synonymous with philosophy is not even sincerely professed in our colleges[æ’å›¾].
Shall we always study to obtain more of these things, and not sometimes to be content with less?
An abode without birds is like a meat without seasoning.
to be streaming with perspiration at undergoing such a roasting.
All intelligences awake with the morning.
Renew thyself completely each day; and forever again.
I have, as it were, my own sun and moon and stars, and a little world all to myself.
â€œI am monarch of all I survey,My right there is none to dispute.â€
Instead of singing like the birds, I silently smiled at my incessant good fortune.

However mean your life is, meet it and live it; do not shun it and call it hard names.It is not so bad as you are.It looks poorest when you are richest. The fault-finder will find faults even in paradise.Love your life, poor as it is
You can either travel or read, but either your body or soul must be on the way

A lake is the landscape's most beautiful and expressive feature.It is earth's eye; looking into which the beholder measures the depth of his own nature.The fluviatile[æ’å›¾] trees next the shore are the slender eyelashes which fringe it, and the wooded hills and cliffs around are its overhanging brows.
was now in a civilized country, where...people are judged of by their clothes.
Not till we are lost, in other words not till we have lost the world, do we begin to find ourselves, and realize where we are and the infinite extent of our relations.
Shams[æ’å›¾] and delusions[æ’å›¾] are esteemed for soundest truths, while reality is fabulous.
I had three chairs in my house; one for solitude, two for friendship, three for society.
to discover new satellites to Neptune, and not detect the motes in his eyes[æ’å›¾]
God is aloneâ€”but the devil, he is far from being alone; he sees a great deal of company;

I believe that every man who has ever been earnest to preserve his higher or poetic faculties in the best condition has been particularly inclined to abstain from animal food, and from much food of any kind.
the cost of a thing is the amount of what I will call life which is required to be exchanged for it, immediately or in the long run.
It would put nations on the alert.Who would not be early to rise, and rise earlier and earlier every successive day of his life, till he became unspeakably healthy, wealthy, and wise[æ’å›¾]
Those things for which the most money is demanded are never the things which the student most wants.
The rays which stream through the shutter will be no longer remembered when the shutter is wholly removed
Most men appear never to have considered what a house is, and are actually though needlessly poor all their lives because they think that they must have such a one as their neighbors have.
Morning is when I am awake and there is a dawn in me.

chapters.title: Where I Lived, and What I Lived For
You can either travel or read, but either your body or soul must be on the way
